Situation1: They share their work challenges and personal concerns after noticing their spouse seems worried.
Situation2: A winter storm is slowing traffic while the passenger must catch an international flight
Story:
I glanced at the clock on the dashboard, my hands gripping the steering wheel as snowflakes battered the windshield. The airport was still miles away, and my passenger kept checking his watch, his anxiety filling the cab. He’d told me his flight was international—missing it wasn’t an option. I felt the weight of his expectation: get him there safely, and on time, despite the storm.

But my phone buzzed in the cupholder. It was my husband. He’d sounded off this morning, and I’d promised we’d talk tonight. He wanted me to open up, to share what was on my mind, just as he was trying to do. I knew he needed me to be present, to listen, to be honest about my own worries. But right now, my mind was split—half on the icy roads, half on the conversation waiting at home.

The storm outside mirrored the one inside me. I wanted to be the wife who listened, who shared, who cared. But I was also the driver, responsible for a stranger’s urgent journey. The demands pulled at me from both sides, and I could feel myself fraying, unsure which role to answer first.
